user_request: A short poem about a raven that visits a grieving man and repeats one word.
final_poem:
He found the raven perched on the fence
at six o'clock, that dark communion,
and said what anyone says to black birds
in a yard where the earth has not been dug.

The bird did not turn. Sits with one leg lifted,
the other foot spreading the cracked soil.
Gives him no eye-contact. Only the sound—
a word he keeps repeating: *lenient.*

All afternoon it sits and says *lenient,*
says it louder when a car drives by,
says it softer when the front door opens,
as if testing how much grief can hold.

He does not correct it. He watches
the raven finish one maggot, swallow,
and rise on that column of air
with its single word still under its breath.
